ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: A basic ecology class could have been made a prerequisite. Landscape ecology was not adequate.
This course taught me more than any other single course that I have taken at FES. Yes, it is fast-paced. Yes, it is hard. But this is a master's program; more classes should be this challenging.
This was a very intense, fast-paced course, but I learned an immense amount and the instructor was great.

The course structure could have been used in a way to better facilitate learning. The homework assignments were good, but the lab sections were not used effectively. It would have been helpful to have weekly lab exercises that were done during the lab sessions. This could have done a lot for improving R coding skills and exposing students to different models/techniques/etc. There could have also been a couple of lab sessions that were exclusively dedicated to building foundational math skills, such as basics of linear algebra and differential equations.

1)R book helpful, Schmitz book helpful, Loreau less so. What the course needed was an even more basic ecology text to promote modelling. I ended up consulting gotelli's intro to ecology text which I had used for a previous course quite a lot on the basics which are difficult to trace from lectures.9)The take home labs were really helpful. The lab time was a bit more awkward. Maybe so more working through basics together or allowing us to start work of the lab and then ask questions as they arose would have made it more helpful. Often Dr. Schmitz seemed frustrated that we didn't have more questions, but they were more likely to come after we started work on the problem set. The modelling project workshop days were helpful more when Dr. Schmitz allowed individual students to approach with questions rather then want students to inquire in front of the entire class.
Why are they rating questions? Why cannot I just enter text, properly explaining my complex feelings regarding the course?

a tendency for a "come'on guys, this isn't rocket science" attitude, even though many concepts were very advanced for those in the class.difficult to reconcile the complexity of the math at times with expectations of only a bit of experience with calculus

This class touched on most of the areas that I felt I was deficient in ecology. Every lecture was intriguing and the assignments were challenging. For me, this was the most useful class I could have hoped to take in graduate school.

I learned entirely new material at a level of mastery that I can be proud of. I now have a much greater understanding of scientific literature and I can understand significantly more of the published research.
The instructor was great and I found the material very interesting.
The material was fantastic. It was a rigorous and accessible introduction to ecological modeling, which I have been looking for. The topics covered in the course were also cutting edge.
It presented a new way of viewing and analyzing the ecosystems we look at
The final project
-The modeling applications that Os discussed to apply the concepts to reality-The labwork
Applicable to real life understanding of system function through combination of theoretcal concepts and emperical examples
The material
Readings, lectures, and assignments. The best part of the class was the overall understanding of food web dynamics you walk away with.
It really challenged me to seek out my own answers and be a better student. I feel that I learned a lot, even though there was a lot of material that was completely over my head.
Really learning to grapple with equations and population ecology concepts. I finally understand how modeling works. Final project was a great way to apply things.

This course helped me feeling comfortable looking at equations in scientific papers, which is something that has been a real challenge. It was great to have a serious ecology course that challenged a lot of my assumptions.
Extremely useful for learning history, theory, and math.
Historical focus really got me to understand the origins of the field. That was fascinating. Also being able to look at theoretical papers and have some idea of what was going one was very rewarding.

Dr Schmitzs availability, willingness to help, and dedication to the topic. The emphasis on theoretical understanding and critical analysis of the theory rather than just memorization.Any given explanation of a concept was well detailed and easily comprehensible.The weekly problem sets and the final modeling project were extremely helpful and appropriate tests of knowledge.
the subject materialan inspired teacher
The focus on critical reading of scientific literature. Also, the fact that I am now able to understand how dynamic systems models are constructed is a huge plus.

The professor was very candid, and so presented the material in an interesting way. We learned hands on how to do some of the programming, so the course went beyond just learning the theory. This was very helpful.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Having three big assignments at the end of the class (final, take-home final and HUGE modeling project) was a bit rough. Spacing them out a bit might be better.
Better use of lab time.

the distance between theory and application was too great. I was unable to take the lesons and directly apply them to something I can see in nature. This may be because there were far more conversations about calculations that actual ecosystems
Trying to understand stability analyses

-The point of the course at which we develop our own modeling skills and apply and synthesize the modeling techniques we've learned. I still don't feel that I understand the full range of modeling techniques, nor do I grasp how they build on one another. The lecture that was supposed to show us how to think through building our own model was too conceptual - would have been more constructive to work through several scenarios together and brainstorm what terms to put together to form a model for the system.-The section on metapopulations didn't seem to fit well with the rest of the class, which focused on predator-prey dynamics. Better integration necessary, or skip it.-Would be helpful to wait another week or two before introducing the final project, since it wasn't yet clear what kind of a question or system we could build a model for.-Move Lab Assignment #6 earlier in the semester. I learned the most from this lab because it forced me to look for what was wrong in given equations and also build my own model. Would have been more helpful 1-2 weeks earlier to help me understand how to start on my own final project model.

I believe a TA would be helpful in this course. Additional either lab or special sessions to work through R syntax would be helpful- escpcially for people who have had no computer programming experience.

The amount of work and expectations for this course were unreasonable.More explicit emphasis on conservation implications.Handouts with the formulas would be helpful - having a foundational resource would allow us to engage more in the discussion and less on trying to discern and write down all the parameters on the board.More in-class group activities and case-study examples (the ones we had were great).
Lectures could be better organized or outlined to provide better coherence. A key concepts handout/reading at the beginning of the class would help get the class up to speed earlier in the course.

The pace and the clarity of information provided. Often the professor contradicted himself and that made things confusing. I would have especially liked a greater amount of work with defining parts of the equations at the beginning of the semester. A simple workshop or even a printed worksheet would have saved me a lot of struggling with the concepts and freed my mind to focus on larger applications and concepts. Also, I feel that at least one lab period should have been spent doing a group walk through of the R software and language. If we had all sat down and been given a tutorial with our lap tops in front of us, I might have gained a quicker insight to R that again would have saved me headaches and allowed me to focus on learning other things.

Problem sets are too time intensive for a 3-credit course. Made it so we didn't have much time to do the reading. More thoughts about how wildlife managers can actually apply knowledge that is already available-- rather than just discussions of how hard things are and what the limitations are-- would be nice. (If any constructive advice actually exists.)

More written materials that clearly and simply explain the fundamental concepts. There is often confusion among variables (P could be plant, prey, predator) so that would be a really helpful supplement to the notes. I think an early quiz that would force students to memorize some of the basics of the equations would be good.
Could have used a higher volume of practice problems.

Dr. Schmitiz is great one on one and really encouraging. In front of a class, however, he seems a little less sure of himself and perhaps as a result gets what appears to be frustrated (long sighs etc.) at student's questions. This perpetuates an atmosphere where many do not feel comfortable asking questions, which then frustrates Dr. Schmitz because he wants people to ask questions particulary during the lab time. Bad cycle.Otherwise course was great. Lots of work, but I think it was worth it.

Less reading or perhaps fewer assignments so as to be able to really learn those we choose to focus on. Better integration of outside class work with lecture material.Lab time could have been used more efficiently than just reviewing past problem sets and fielding individual questions. Running model simulations or learning specific R script throughout the term would have been better.The papers seemed too formulaic to be truly educational and the knowledge I gained from them would probably have been better accessed via testing.Because discussion so frequently oscillated between present theory and historical development it was hard to place things in context. Because so few of the issues have been satisfyingly resolved it was easy to grow confused over whether the debate and associated concerns over a specific issue dated to 30 years ago or were contemporary. Either a completely temporally driven syllabus or a completely topic based one, rather than an oscillation between the two, would have been helpful.

I'm not sure how this would be possible, but I didn't feel like I had all the tools to even conceive of a final project idea until after we had done all of the assignments. The last one in particular helped me put everything together in my head. I don't think that we could have sped up the pace of the course, but the lab days that we had to work on our final projects might have been more useful to me later in the semester.

It would be very helpful to have better supporting material ie power point slides from lectures that could be made available to the students for study. The course started out a bit too fast, it would have been helpful to have a bit more explanation of the opening mathematical concepts.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The professor was always prompt to requests for additional help outside of class time.

The instructor did a great job explaining concepts and going through equations. I'm not naturally good at math, but I felt like I was able to follow along just fine when he went through things. Also, the instructor was always very helpful and willing to meet with students to go through individual questions.
The instructor was very available and helpful.
Very high - excellent availability and quality of help. Thank you.
I did not seek help as often as I should have
There was no TA, but Os was very available to help.

The professor answered emails when asked and was willing to meet about the final project but with a class this intense I would have liked an offer of open hours or help sessions. I know the he is a busy man but we are also busy students and could use all the help we can get especially with the challenging homework material that he assigns!Perhaps the homeworks could have been made during the lecture after a class period so that lecture time could be used more efficiently to ask questions about homeworks that we have had time to work on rather than turning assignments in and then being assigned a new homework and then having time to ask questions all in the same lab period.
Dr. Schmitz was always available for questions from students.
Very available, very helpful.
The professor was incredibly accommodating with student questions and schedules - it was clear he wanted us to get the material.

The instructor was very responsive and helpful when I asked questions. But it is a JOKE that there was no TA for this class! Of all the classes I have taken or expect to take, this is the one that needed it the most. There are simply some issues that need further explanation or clarification but that are not important enough to reach out to the instructor.

The professor obviously cared deeply about the course and put in a ton of effort himself which made the huge amount of work that we needed to do more easy to justify.He was always available to meet one on one and answered emails promptly.
Instructoravailable whenever needed either via email or in person, always fully sufficient to answer my questions.
He always makes himself available to talk in person and is extremely responsive by email.
The instructor taught the lab which as great. He was very open to questions and available to help.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: As an undergrad/5th year MESc program student this course provided a much-needed upper level ecology class. I wish there were more courses like this available!
It does not really fit well into the program. the class seems more applicable to people going into dynamics research
Anyone looking at species specific or landscape ecology should take this course

I feel that it really helped me gain a background understanding into modeling and has already helped me to better read published literature. It has also taught me that I never want to do a modeling project.

My focus is conservation, with an emphasis on ecology. Surprisingly there are very few relevant courses at FES or EEB, this course is one of the few that clearly fits in. It helped provide the biological basis to a lot of ideas that will work with in the future.
Good background on ecological theory and mathematics for future work in ecology.
Theoretical and historical background to the field that I will be working in.

This course provided a great foundation for me. I feel much better equipped to handle the literature that I will need to know in the future and I have a much better understanding of some of the classical papers in ecology.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: As a prep for Conservation Biology.
I took this course because it sounded interesting and relevant to my area of study (the interface of community, landscape and ecosystem ecology in freshwater systems).
Interest.
I thought it would be a useful introduction to conservation biology course and share some of the same lessons
Academic interests
Wanted to build quantitative analysis skills and learn how to model ecological systems. Plan to apply skills acquired to future research.
Applicable to my field
For an introduction to dynamical modeling and food web ecology.
To get a more solid grounding in ecology and to get some experience with R.
It's one of the few animal biology courses available. I wanted to work on my math skills and it's relevant for my future path.
To learn how to model ecological systems.
Get a handle on modelling and and dynamics, more experience with R.
To grow comfortable with model based thinking in biology.
Personal interest, recommendation by advisor.
I think the course provided an essential foundation for anyone interested in theoretical ecology. I felt it was essential to have exposure to concepts in population ecology.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: It surpassed them.
Yes, it was definitely challenging as I expected, but totally worth it!
To some extent. I was hoping to come away with more model programming skills. Everything else was great.
Not completely
Yes
Yes.
Yes
yes.
Exceeded them in many ways, although I don't feel as fluent with R as I thought I would be.

It was hard. I knew it would be. I think I expected more as far as my feeling of understanding and how things relate to the real world, but I don't know if that was reasonable. The final assignments helped me see what I had learned in the class.
Yes
yep.
yes
Yes, this was the best class I have taken thus far at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
Yes.
See above
The course did not have as much to do with conservation biology as I thought
Yes
Yes, and more!
Yes
yes and more.
Yes. It was very overwhelming until about the second-to-last week, but then things started coming together.
yep + history of field
yes
Yes. I will admit that it was quite a bit of work, but all the assignments made me feel like I was keeping up with the new information.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I think that working in a group in this course both informally in homework and test study groups and formally on the final project really helped me to better grasp the material through the merit of explaining things to others aloud and having the opportunity to ping ideas off of each other. It also helped me to avoid complete frustration and melt down during the most difficult assignments.

It was great to do the project with a partner to have someone to bounce ideas off of and make sure I really understood what was going on. We ended up doing the problem sets in study groups too, which was helpful and good for morale.
I don't know what this means. Yes I met with a few other students to work on problem sets etc.? That was helpful, but it was informal and not part of the course.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Much like landscape ecology, stay on top of your readings and review weekly notes with others in class. I failed to do it this time and fell behind. Also, while the course might seem difficult at first - you WILL get to a point where you understand the theory - even if you do not have an ecology background. Just takes a bit longer.
Be prepared to work hard! Review your notes EVERY DAY. It will really help in terms of understanding the material!
Make sure to meet with Os when needed and pay attention in class. Also, studying with other students in the class is really helpful.
Do the readings and spend time on the model early.
Stick with it! Its intimidating at first but Os is understanding and does a great job explaining theoretical concepts.
Spend time learning R language
Take it, it is arguably one of the best courses offered and essential for environmental managers wanting to develop a complex systems approach for addressing ecological problems.
Be prepared to read, study, and be frustrated A LOT!
Be sure you have a lot of time to spend on it, and do the problem sets with friends.
Study the basic equations and know them cold. The course is going to be hard, but ask lots of questions. Don't let things linger if you're confused or unsure. Start the modeling project early.

Know what you want before you take it. It will be a course you were glad that you took, but it will be a ton of work so know that you really want to know the material and are willing to put in the time.

Grow accustomed to seeing authors as people who you must keep track of and read papers always in the context of those who come before and after. Not only will it make course work much easier, but it is inherently a better way of conceptualizing the development of biological thought.
Be prepared to work. Having an understanding of the instructor's system and an interest in modeling and/or dynamic systems in general will be very helpful.
